Origami.name: Origami
Origami.description: Origami is a team dedicated to computer graphics and covers all aspects of this discipline, with three main themes: geometry, rendering and simulation. In digital geometry, our work focuses on the development of algorithms for the analysis and creation of meshes, point clouds, digital surfaces and procedural shapes for virtual worlds. In rendering, we focus on the simulation of lighting, sampling, virtual reality and perception. Finally, in simulation, we develop deformation and fluid models, as well as their discretization: M2Disco, Ream, Geomod.

Imagine.name: Imagine
Imagine.infos_name: Computer vision, Machine learning, Pattern recognition
Imagine.description: The LIRIS Imagine team specializes in computer vision, learning and pattern recognition.  The various research activities carried out by the Imagine team share the same general objectives of understanding multi-source and multi-sensor images, thus integrating a very wide variety of content around images of people, objects and scenes in 2D and 3D, image sequences and video streams, as well as digitized documents (maps, written and printed texts, scores and symbols...). The notion of the visual object, in the broadest sense, is thus a common denominator in our research. The Imagine team's activities are divided into different themes linked to the implementation of methods for indexing, modeling, classifying and recognizing content (objects, actions, concepts), with a particular focus on the development of machine learning methods for computer vision. The research carried out by the Imagine team aims to build bridges across the semantic divide between, on the one hand, the low-level information present in raw data (sampled data from signals), possible multi-source data from other modalities or sensors (particularly in the case of embedded applications) and, on the other hand, the higher-level semantic information based on content modeling, classification and identification.
keywords_description: computer vision, learning and pattern recognition
machine learning methods for computer vision

BD.name: BD
BD.description: The Data Base team is part of the LIRIS “Data Science” division (UMR 5205 CNRS). The team's activities focus on the principles, techniques and applications of data management systems. In this context, the data to be considered are produced by a variety of sources (conventional data, sensor data, data from services, etc.) and the applications rely on a variety of storage media (e.g. RAM, Flash, disk) with very different technical characteristics. We borrow our methods from the fields of databases, both at the theoretical level (algebraic and logical languages, data dependencies) and at the system level (storage techniques, indexing and query optimization).Our scientific objectives focus on data storage, querying and analysis, but also on data/service coupling, declarative query languages for new applications - notably intelligent buildings - and data confidentiality and security. The team structures its activities around the following three themes: Theme 1: Management of dynamic environments. Theme 2: Data quality, integrity and availability. Theme 3: Security and confidentiality of data and services.  It should be noted that the application theme of intelligent buildings has mobilized many of the team's permanent staff across the three themes.
keywords_description: Security and confidentiality of data and services

DM2L.name: DM2L
DM2L.description: DM2L (Data Mining & Machine Learning) is a scientific team created in 2012 whose research activity is devoted to Knowledge Discovery from Data based on automatic or semi-automatic techniques. This includes data mining, machine learning, pattern recognition, data analysis, natural language processing, etc.

GOAL.name: GOAL
GOAL.description: The GOAL team's activities focus on the combinatorial and algorithmic aspects of graphs. 3 lines of research emerge from these activities: Combinatorics. The fundamental research of team members concerns the study of structures (plunging, decompositions, matchings, etc.) and optimization parameters on graphs (colorations, identifications, combinatorial games, etc.). Algorithms. The algorithmic dimension concerns the study of complexity and the development of efficient algorithms for highlighting properties or evaluating parameters on graphs. These algorithms can be sequential, distributed, self-stabilizing or dynamic. Applications. The GOAL team is interested in the applications of graphs in Big Data, the Web, distributed architectures and security, among others.

members.employer: National Institute of Applied Sciences of Lyon
National Institute of Applied Sciences of Lyon

SyCoSMA.name: SyCoSMA
SyCoSMA.description: The Cognitive Systems and Multi-Agent Systems team's research focuses on the field of artificial intelligence (AI), proposing new computer models and solutions, based on the multi-agent paradigm, to support the evolution of current computer systems and anticipate that of future systems, in a context of data and knowledge massification, dynamics, large-scale distribution and algorithmic and systemic complexity. Our research in this field is part of a constructivist vision, considering representations as dynamic constructs that the computer system elaborates on the basis of its experience of interaction with its environment, and through learning mechanisms and self* mechanisms (self-organization, self-adaptation, self-development) that enable its autonomy. Research topics: Multi-Agent Learning, Self-* Systems and Autonomy, Interaction and Coordination Models. We are involved in the main themes of assistance systems, including service robotics for dependent people, with a strong focus on mechanism design, transport regulation and intelligent energy management.

TWEAK.name: TWEAK
TWEAK.description: The work of the TWEAK team falls within the disciplines of symbolic artificial intelligence and knowledge engineering (KE), and more specifically explores two dimensions: HALEs (Computer Environments for Human Learning) and the Web. We are particularly interested in the explicability of the processes implemented by the systems we develop, and in the co-evolution of user-machine systems within computerized environments, adopting a knowledge-oriented point of view. We evaluate our proposals through prototypes and tools that we experiment with in a number of fields, from MOOCs to the Web of Things. Our work in IC focuses in particular on knowledge dynamics engineering, in which modeled traces constitute a representation of experience and an important source of knowledge. We propose the notion of a Trace Base Management System, specified and implemented within an open platform. These systems, coupled with instrumentation of traced IT systems, place the user in a central role for the co-construction and exploitation of knowledge. To this end, we are developing the paradigm of Reasoning from Traced Experience, an interactive and dynamic process in which the transparency of automatic processing allows users to adapt it to their own needs. We also draw on the human and social sciences to support the reflexive use of activity traces. Our work in the field of EIAH aims to propose models for providing the various players in a learning situation (authors of educational content, teachers, learners) with tools designed to support learning. We argue that it is the acquisition of knowledge from these different actors that enables them to contribute to the implementation of a learning environment adapted to each individual's needs. As part of a competency-based approach, we aim to help teachers create pedagogical activities, monitor their students and implement adaptive teaching. Exploiting the traces of interaction between learners and an EIAH can also support the self-regulation of learning, through the creation of open competency profiles, enabling both the learner to set goals and the system to recommend personalized activities.

SICAL.name: SICAL
SICAL.infos_name: Situated Interaction, Collaboration, Adaptation and Learning
SICAL.description: The SICAL team proposes generic approaches, models and tools to enhance the ability of humans to interact, learn and adapt in context, in order to address several scientific challenges: Facilitating co-located collaboration between humans in eco-systems of heterogeneous digital devices, Enabling explicability and control of intelligent systems, Giving meaning to spatial data and learning data (machine and human), Designing technologies for well-being and behavior change.

DRIM.name: DRIM
DRIM.description: The DRIM team's work focuses on 3 themes: digital documents and semantic information retrieval, robust data management and sharing in distributed and mobile systems, and trust, reputation and privacy in distributed systems. The team focuses on work at the interface of these three themes, with e-health, digital humanities and the intelligent city as its main areas of application. The vast majority of our research is conducted in close partnership with the Universities of Passau and Milan, as part of the MDPS international doctoral program.
keywords_description: digital documents and semantic information retrieval
sharing in distributed and mobile systems
reputation and privacy in distributed systems
e-health, digital humanities and the intelligent city

SOC.name: SOC
SOC.description: SOC's work is organized along 3 axes to overcome the obstacles to the generalization of the service concept, and to the protection of data and services in large-scale, open and uncertain environments: Foundations and theoretical models for services, Service security and security services, Holistic service model and methods for designing and deploying XaaS services for SMACIT.
keywords_description: Foundations and theoretical models for services
methods for designing and deploying XaaS services for SMACIT

members.employer: National Institute of Applied Sciences of Lyon
National Institute of Applied Sciences of Lyon

Beagle.name: Beagle
Beagle.description: Beagle's research focuses on computational biology and artificial evolution (digital genetics). We position ourselves at the interface between computer science and the life sciences, in order to generate new knowledge in biology through modeling and simulation. In other words, we create artifacts - from the Latin artis factum (an entity created by man rather than nature) - and explore them in order to understand nature. Our research is therefore based on an interdisciplinary strategy: we develop computational formalisms and software tools for modeling complex systems in synergy with various biology teams with whom we maintain close links. This “digital sciences” (or computational sciences) approach enables us to study abstractions of biological systems or processes, in order to uncover the organizational principles of cellular systems in a systems biology perspective.
keywords_description: interface between computer science and the life sciences
uncover the organizational principles of cellular systems

SAARA.name: SAARA
SAARA.infos_name: Simulation, Analyse et Animation pour la Réalité Augmentée
SAARA.description: Our research themes concern the simulation, analysis and animation of complex scenes involving moving virtual humans, with an orientation towards Augmented Reality environments.
keywords_description: simulation, analysis and animation of complex scenes

Computer graphics and geometry.name: Computer graphics and geometry
Computer graphics and geometry.description: This division covers the entire image production chain, from modeling to image synthesis. In particular, it focuses upstream on problems of acquisition, modeling, analysis and synthesis of geometries in various forms (meshes, point clouds, digital geometries). It then focuses on problems of deformation and animation of these geometries via physical simulations. Finally, at the end of the chain come the issues of textures and rendering, whether physically realistic or real-time.

Image, vision and learning.name: Image, vision and learning
Image, vision and learning.description: The various research activities carried out in this division share the same general objectives, aimed at understanding multi-source and multi-sensor images, thus integrating a very wide variety of content that revolves around the visual object (images of people, objects and scenes in 2D and 3D), activities (movement, gestures, actions), and concepts (scene semantics, induced emotions). These objectives revolve around the implementation of methods and models for the recognition, analysis and understanding of these contents, in a controlled articulation between the contributions of computer vision and machine learning.

Algorithms and Combinatorics.name: Algorithms and Combinatorics
Algorithms and Combinatorics.description: In computer science, discrete and combinatorial structures are used to model a wide range of objects: networks, databases, tables, images, web services... This division brings together teams seeking to understand the fundamental properties governing these structures, and then to design and analyze algorithms for these same objects. Research in this division is both structural (existence of combinatorial properties, enumeration, construction of new discrete models) and algorithmic (calculation of theoretical complexity, exact and approximate algorithms, distributed algorithms, verification and formal proofs).

Data, System and Security.name: Data, Systems and Security
Data, System and Security.description: This division conducts research into data and knowledge (e.g. databases, data mining, data masses, learning, knowledge engineering, semantic web, information retrieval), systems aspects (e.g. distributed systems, large-scale infrastructures, grids, cloud) and system and data security (e.g. privacy, reliability).

Simulation and life sciences.name: Simulation and life sciences
Simulation and life sciences.description: The research carried out in this division aims to acquire, understand, model, simulate and restore the surrounding world. To achieve this, we use a variety of computer and mathematical tools. We digitally reproduce elements of the universe that surrounds us, in order to conduct virtual experiments or anticipate the design of artificial objects. By its very nature, this division is multidisciplinary, with strong links to various fields of biology, physics, medicine and engineering.

Cognition and Interaction.name: Cognition and Interaction
Cognition and Interaction.description: The research carried out in this division aims to study and design dynamic systems in which several agents, human or software, interact. The focus is on studying the properties (cognitive, behavioral, emotional, etc.) of both individual agents and the resulting system. In this area, agents are considered as objects of study, with the aim of developing models/systems that exhibit individual and collective intelligence, reasoning, decentralized processing and control, and adaptation. The user-machine pair is seen as a single learning system, co-evolving as a function of the activities carried out.
